title: R42445
content: Surface transportation authorization acts authorize spending on federal highway and mass transit programs, safety, research, and some rail programs. The most recent authorization, SAFETEA-LU, expired in 2009, leading to operations on extension acts and resolutions due to budget constraints. The highway trust fund has been the primary funding source. The highway trust fund (HTF) has been the main source of funding for surface transportation bills since 1956. However, declining revenues from highway taxes, due to the economy and improved fuel efficiency, have raised concerns about passing a multi-year bill without cutting spending, raising gas taxes, or increasing the deficit. Other debated issues include alternative finance, tolling, public-private partnerships, project delivery acceleration, and performance management in this fiscal context. In the fiscal context, issues of equity in federal spending distribution among states are being debated. The Senate passed MAP-21 on March 14, 2012, reauthorizing surface transportation programs. For more details, refer to CRS Report R41512. The House committees reported favorably on H.R. 7, a five-year bill reauthorizing surface transportation programs with a total authorization of $260 billion. The bill includes provisions to increase oil and gas production to fund highway infrastructure, which has sparked controversy. The House passed the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2012, Part II (H.R. 4348) to extend surface transportation authorizations through FY2012, including provisions for the Keystone XL Pipeline and Gulf Coast Restoration Trust Fund. The Senate agreed to an amendment that replaced the House-passed language in H.R. 4348 with the language of MAP-21, allowing the measure to go to conference. Negotiations will involve the substance of H.R. 7 and provisions of the extension bill. Surface transportation reauthorization is a complex issue before Congress, involving multiple committees. The highway trust fund is primarily funded by excise taxes on motor fuels. The Highway Trust Fund (HTF) is funded by taxes on motor fuels, with rates set at 18.3 cents per gallon for gasoline and 24.3 cents per gallon for diesel. The HTF has two separate accounts for highway and mass transit, with the highway account receiving 15.44 cents of the gasoline tax and the mass transit account receiving 2.86 cents. Fuel tax revenues do not increase with inflation as they are set in cents per gallon. The last fuel tax rate increase was in 1993, and sluggish economic performance and improved vehicle fuel efficiency have led to lower than expected revenues. The Highway Trust Fund has faced reduced fuel tax revenues, requiring transfers from the general fund. The Congressional Budget Office projects a shortfall of $4.6 billion by the end of FY2013, with a gap of $8-9 billion per year through FY2022. The mass transit account faces a projected shortfall of $1.2 billion by the end of FY2014, increasing to $5 billion by the end of FY2015. Without an increase in fuel taxes, the trust fund system will struggle to support transportation spending. The Federal-Aid Highway Program (Highway Program) may not be able to support current or increased surface transportation spending without new revenue sources. State DOTs primarily manage the program but must adhere to federal planning guidelines. The Federal-Aid Highway Program is managed by state DOTs according to federal planning guidelines. Projects require a state/local matching share, typically 10% for Interstate System projects and 20% for other roads. FHWA notifies states of federal funds availability for four years, with funds distributed through apportionment. The Federal-Aid Highway Program distributes federal funds through apportionment, allocation, and reimbursement. Reimbursement is provided once a project is approved and costs are incurred, to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse. Contract authority allows for obligation without appropriation. The Federal-Aid Highway Program distributes federal funds through apportionment, allocation, and reimbursement. Contract authority allows for obligation without appropriation, with liquidating authority needed to pay obligations. Obligation of contract authority legally commits the federal government to reimburse the state for project costs. Limitation on obligations (ObLim) controls annual spending, similar to an appropriation. Formula and discretionary programs receive funds, with formula program funds apportioned to each state. Under SAFETEA, federal-aid highway money is apportioned to state DOTs through large formula-driven programs, which receive 80% of contract authority. These core formula programs, such as the Interstate Maintenance Program (IM), fund most federal-aid highway projects. Discretionary programs, on the other hand, are smaller programs allocated by FHWA or earmarked by Congress. The core formula programs for federal-aid highway projects include Interstate Maintenance Program (IM), National Highway System (NHS), Surface Transportation Program (STP), Highway Bridge Program (HBP), Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality Improvement (CMAQ) Program, Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP), and Equity Bonus Program (EB). Each program has its own formula factors to determine state apportionment of funds. The Equity Bonus Program, the largest highway program in dollar terms, guarantees each state a minimum share of funds regardless of funding formulas. State DOTs have increasing flexibility to transfer funds between programs, reducing the importance of funding formulas and program eligibility distinctions. Some argue that the program structure limits their ability to use federal highway funds as they see fit. Highway Program funding can also be used for transit projects. The Equity Bonus Program guarantees each state a minimum share of funds regardless of funding formulas, diluting the policy rationales associated with core program formulas. Smaller discretionary highway programs are also part of the Federal-Aid Highway Program, earmarked by Congress during SAFETEA. The term "program" is used broadly in FHWA's Financing Federal-Aid Highways listing. The Federal Transit Administration administers various individual programs with different funding amounts, distribution mechanisms, and spending rules. There are four main federal transit programs in SAFETEA, accounting for 85% of authorized funds. The Urbanized Area Formula Program and the Fixed Guideway Modernization Program are two of the main federal transit programs in SAFETEA, accounting for 57% of authorized transit funding. The Urbanized Area Formula Program provides funding to urbanized areas with populations of 50,000 or more, while the Fixed Guideway Modernization Program funds are mainly used for transit replacement and rehabilitation. 16% of authorized transit funding is allocated for the replacement and rehabilitation of transit rail system assets. The New Starts Program, accounting for 18% of overall funding, is competitive and supports new fixed guideway systems and extensions, including busways, ferries, and vintage trolleys. Additionally, the "Small Starts" program in SAFETEA funds projects with a total cost of $250. Congress enacted the "Small Starts" program in SAFETEA to fund projects with a total cost of $250 million or less, with a federal share of $75 million or less. Small Starts projects receive $200 million annually from the New Starts authorization starting in FY2007. Bus Program funds, 9% of authorized funding, are used to purchase buses and bus-related equipment, as well as for building construction. Previously earmarked, these funds are now allocated by the FTA. The FTA allocates funds for various transit programs, with smaller programs like the Rural Formula Program, JARC, Elderly and Disabilities grants, and New Freedom Program accounting for 15% of funds. Highway transportation is a leading cause of fatalities and injuries in the US, with states responsible for highway safety. Congress has federal highway safety programs to assist states. The Department of Transportation (DOT) administers federal highway safety programs to assist states in improving highway safety. Three DOT agencies oversee these programs: NHTSA focuses on driver behavior and vehicle safety, FMCSA focuses on commercial driver qualifications and vehicle safety, and FHWA focuses on roadway design safety. NHTSA provides grants to states, regulates motor vehicle safety, and conducts research on traffic safety. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) oversees federal grant funds for traffic safety, requiring states to submit approved highway safety plans to receive funds. Each state's plan must identify primary safety problems, set goals, and establish performance measures. NHTSA also provides training and grants through various programs. FMCSA administers various grant programs to support state efforts in improving traffic safety, including reducing speeding, increasing seat belt usage, and discouraging unsafe driving behaviors. It also promotes commercial motor vehicle safety through regulation, enforcement, training, and technical assistance. The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) administers motor carrier safety grant programs to ensure the safety of truck and motor coach operations. The Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP) aims to reduce traffic fatalities and injuries by improving roadways. States receive funding based on road lane-miles, vehicle miles traveled, and traffic fatalities, with a minimum allocation of 0.5%. HSIP includes a set-aside for the Railway-Highway Grade Crossing Hazard Elimination Program. SAFETEA extended funding mechanisms to protect highway and mass transit budgets from being reallocated for other purposes. It guaranteed annual funding levels for high-risk rural roads and specified funding levels for FY2005 through FY2009. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 specified SAFETEA ObLim levels to prevent lower funding levels. Budget firewalls set in the Budget Enforcement Act were honored by appropriators until 2002. A change in House rules provided a second level of protection, but it was eliminated in the 112th Congress, removing the guarantees. RABA can adjust funding levels annually. RABA is a mechanism for adjusting highway funding levels based on annual account receipts. Despite revenues consistently falling below guarantee levels, funding cuts have not been implemented due to general fund transfers. Consideration for aligning spending with receipts may still be needed. Some mechanism to align spending with receipts may still be necessary for reauthorization, as the Budget Control Act requires sequestration if a special joint committee fails to agree on spending reductions. However, exemptions under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act likely mean sequestration would not significantly reduce surface transportation spending. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act exemptions indicate that sequestration would not significantly reduce surface transportation spending beyond FY2012. Exempted programs include Federal-Aid Highways, Highway Traffic Safety Grants, NHTSA operations, Motor Carrier Safety programs, Transit Formula and Bus Grants. The $739 million annual contract authority exempt from obligation limitation may be subject to sequester. The Federal Transit Administration's New Starts program, supported by general fund revenues, is also affected. The Transit Administration's New Starts program, funded by general revenues, may be impacted by sequester. SAFETEA expired in 2009, with surface transportation programs operating on extension legislation. The House-passed STEA-II extends the HTF and federal transportation programs until September 30, 2012, with new legislative provisions. The Senate replaced this with MAP-21 on April 24, 2012. The House and Senate sent the two-year surface transportation bill and the House extension legislation, MAP-21 and STEA-II, to conference for negotiation. Chairman John Mica stated that the negotiation would include the substance of H.R. 7. Provisions in conference proposals must align with the differences between the House and Senate versions. The substance of H.R. 7 provisions, not present in either version, is expected to be included. The substance of H.R. 7 provisions, not in the Senate or House versions, is expected to be proposed in conference. Members may raise issues on the allowable scope for conference on H.R. 4348. Conference reports with out-of-scope provisions may face points of order in both chambers. House can waive content restrictions with a majority vote, while Senate requires 60 Senators' support. Title II of the STEA-II bill includes provisions related to the North American Energy Access Act, transferring permitting authority for the Keystone XL pipeline, and requiring a permit to be issued within 30 days of enactment. It also states that the final environmental impact statement from August 26, 2011, satisfies all requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The bill establishes the Gulf Coast Restoration Trust Fund, financed by 80% of Deepwater Horizon-related penalties under the Clean Water Act. The Secretary of the Treasury administers the fund, distributing revenues with 35% going to Gulf Coast states. The House-passed H.R. 4348 establishes the Gulf Coast Restoration Trust Fund, distributing revenues with 35% to Gulf Coast states, 60% to the Gulf Coast Ecosystem Restoration Council, and 5% for research. Unlike S. 1400, future revenue distribution would require an act of Congress. The provision ensures budgetary resources match Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund receipts and restricts use to harbor maintenance programs. Title V includes the Coal Residuals Reuse and Management Act. Title V of the House-passed H.R. 4348 adds the Coal Residuals Reuse and Management Act to the bill, allowing states to implement coal combustion residuals permit programs. Title VI, from H.R. 7, aims to expedite transportation project delivery. Both House and Senate bills focus on reducing highway programs and expediting project delivery without earmarks. MAP-21 is a two-year reauthorization bill funding the Federal-Aid Highway Program. MAP-21 is a two-year reauthorization bill that funds the Federal-Aid Highway Program with adjustments for inflation. It includes changes to the structure, formulas, and funding distribution. The bill authorizes $39.5 billion for FY2012 and $40.5 billion for FY2013, with $400 million allocated for research and education each fiscal year. Formula factors under individual programs would be eliminated, and states would receive contract authority based on their previous apportionments and allocations. The MAP-21 bill authorizes funding for the Federal-Aid Highway Program based on states' previous apportionments and allocations. It replaces individual program formulas with a calculation based on SAFETEA share, reducing federal and congressional influence on project selection. MAP-21 would significantly change federal planning and project delivery by eliminating most discretionary grant programs and reducing the number of programs by two-thirds. Transferability between core programs would be limited to 20% of each formula program's apportionment. The Transportation Enhancements Program would be merged into the CMAQ program. The bill merges the Transportation Enhancements Program into the CMAQ program and allows states to use funds for non-TE CMAQ uses after building up an unspent balance. The National Freight Program aims to increase funding for freight projects by eliminating competition with non-freight projects. The Senate bill also significantly increases funding for the Transportation Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act program. The House bill, H.R. 7, is a five-year reauthorization bill with modest increases for federal-aid highways and funding for research and education. It includes provisions to fold existing programs into the National Highway System and Surface Transportation Programs. The bill does not address tolling of federally funded roads and bridges, which are important for revenue streams needed for TIFIA and other projects. The House bill, H.R. 7, proposes reducing the number of distinct programs by two-thirds to around 30. It includes retaining the Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality program and the Highway Safety Improvement programs. The Equity Bonus program would guarantee a 94% state rate of return on payments to the Highway Trust Fund. The Mass Transit Account would be renamed the Alternative Transportation Account and would provide $2.267 billion annually for highway programs. Fuel taxes credited to the Mass Transit Account would be redirected to the Highway Account. The House bill, H.R. 7, proposes redirecting fuel taxes from the Mass Transit Account to the Highway Account. Provisions under the streamlining title would change NEPA requirements for federal highway and transit projects, excluding projects costing less than $10 million or with federal funding below 15%. TIFIA funding would increase significantly, and MAP-21 would maintain current funding levels for the Federal Transit Administration. H.R. 7 proposes changes to transit funding, including the creation of the State of Good Repair program and modifications to the New Starts process. Funding for the Bus and Bus Facilities SGR program would come from the New Starts program. H.R. 7 proposes changes to transit funding, including renaming the Mass Transit Account to the Alternative Transportation Account (ATA) and redirecting motor fuel taxes to the Highway Account. The bill would transfer $40 billion from the general fund to fund the ATA and eliminate various grant programs while combining others into a single program. MAP-21 includes provisions for a national rail plan, rolling stock equipment pool, and positive train control. It also amends the RRIF program to accept state or local subsidies as collateral for freight rail loans. The bill includes provisions for Amtrak funding, the RRIF program, and positive train control implementation. It aims to close the gap between projected HTF revenues and total authorizations. The Senate bill extends highway-related taxes and trust fund expenditure authority. The bill includes provisions to raise $13.872 billion over ten-and-a-half fiscal years for the HTF, with transfers from various sources such as the LUST trust fund, Gas Guzzler Tax, revocation of passports of tax delinquents, and allowing the Treasury to levy payments to Medicare providers. The curr_chunk details various sources of revenue generation, including levying payments to Medicare providers, transfer of import tariffs on automotive products, change in tax treatment of securities, IRS levy on federal employee's Thrift Savings Account, extension for transfers of excess pension assets, and application of U.S. tax code to life insurance. Total revenue raised is $4.52 billion from import tariffs, $244 million from tax treatment change, $25 million from IRS levy, and $363 million from pension asset transfers. The curr_chunk summarizes various revenue sources, including pension funding stabilization, transfer from Treasury general fund to HTF, phased retirement, sale of life insurance policies, and extending taxes. Total revenue generated is $9.467 billion from pension funding, $4.970 billion from Treasury transfer, $459 million from phased retirement, $244 million from life insurance sales, and $99 million from tax extensions. The curr_chunk outlines revenue sources including delaying interest expense allocation, special measures against money laundering, and comments on exceeding offset needs for deficit reduction. The Finance Committee reported favorably on provisions that cost money, including reducing spending levels by $761 million over 10 years, changing the Small Issuer Exception rules, and extending special rules for bonds issued before January 1, 2013. Additionally, $215 million would be saved by not treating certain bonds as a tax preference for alternative minimum tax purposes, and $139 million would be saved by extending the parity of monthly exclusion for employer-provided vanpool and transit pass benefits. The Senate bill includes provisions for TRIP bonds through state infrastructure banks and modified versions of the Sustainable Water Infrastructure Act and the Transportation Access for All Americans Act. The Transportation Access for All Americans Act would amend the Internal Revenue Code to extend the depreciation period for long-term highway leases to 45 years, potentially reducing private-sector investor interest in highway privatization. The bill also ensures that the amortization period for the franchise right to collect tolls is not less than the lease term or 15 years, whichever is longer. The Finance Committee is concerned that the current 15-year amortization period for toll collection rights is often shorter than the lease term. The Finance Committee is proposing a "solvency account" to manage excess funds appropriated to the Highway Trust Fund (HTF) under MAP-21. These funds would be transferred to the highway and mass transit accounts to ensure their needs are met. The Senate bill proposes using the LUST trust fund to provide new revenue for the highway trust fund, which was established in 1986 to address groundwater contamination from leaking underground storage tanks. The fund receives revenues from a tax on gasoline and diesel fuels to support environmental cleanup programs. The LUST trust fund is used for environmental contamination investigation and cleanup programs, as well as UST leak prevention. States use the fund for overseeing corrective actions by responsible parties and conducting actions when no responsible party is identified. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 expanded the fund's use for federal UST leak prevention and detection programs. The LUST trust fund, used for environmental cleanup and UST leak prevention, has addressed 85% of reported releases, with 88,000 still needing cleanup. The fund had a $3.392 billion balance in FY2012, receiving $117 million in interest and $181 million in tax receipts. Congress typically appropriates $113 million annually from the fund for states' grants. The LUST trust fund, used for environmental cleanup and UST leak prevention, has addressed 85% of reported releases, with 88,000 still needing cleanup. States receive a minimum of 80% of the annual appropriation from the fund, while EPA uses the remainder for its responsibilities, including implementing the program on Indian lands. States' LUST programs have relied on nonfederal fund sources due to low appropriations. Section 40301 of the Senate bill would transfer $3.0 billion from the LUST trust fund to the highway trust fund in FY2012, and Section 40302 would appropriate one-third of future LUST trust fund receipts to the highway trust fund. The LUST trust fund receives funds from a tax on gasoline and diesel fuel, projected to provide $3.685 billion to the highway trust fund over ten years. The expenditure authority for the LUST trust fund is set to expire on March 31, 2012, but the Senate bill aims to extend it through September 30, 2013. The finance provisions of H.R. 7 were included in the American Energy and Infrastructure Jobs Financing Act of 2012. The bill H.R. 7 reauthorizes HTF expenditure authority through FY2016 and extends existing highway taxes, including motor fuel taxes, through FY2018. It includes a provision requiring offsets for transfers from the general fund to the HTF. The finance provisions of H.R. 7 aim to reconfigure the highway trust fund and address revenue gaps. H.R. 7 proposes offsets for highway account revenues and balances, including $40 billion from the general fund for an alternative transportation account. It extends the LUST trust fund and aims to direct federal revenues from energy leasing into the Highway Trust Fund. Title XVII of H.R. 7 would allocate government receipts from energy leasing and drilling activities to the Highway Trust Fund. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act governs offshore energy development, allowing the Department of the Interior to lease federal ocean areas for oil and gas resources. The Department of the Interior has the right to develop oil and gas resources in federal ocean areas, generating $6.5 billion in federal receipts in FY2011. These receipts are allocated to various programs, including the Land and Water Conservation Fund and the National Historic Preservation Fund. Additionally, states receive portions of federal receipts from certain submerged acreage. H.R. 7 renames the mass transit account of the HTF to the alternative transportation account and provides a one-time appropriation of $40 billion. Gulf Coast states receive additional funds from specified leases. Federal Employee Retirement is included to provide offsetting revenues for the $40 billion in general fund revenues allocated to the alternative transportation account. MAP-21 proposes total authorizations of $80.8 billion over two years under the Highway and Research titles of the bill. The bill guarantees a state share based on SAFETEA and a 95 cent return on each dollar paid to the highway account. MAP-21 does not include highway program earmarks or reinstate funding firewalls. Section 4001 includes a provision for Highway Spending Controls. Section 4001 of MAP-21 includes a "ratchet mechanism" provision to ensure solvency of the highway account by reducing FY2012 ObLim if balance falls below $2 billion in FY2012 or $1 billion in FY2013. Any withdrawn ObLim would lapse, and a proportionate amount of contract authority would be rescinded. The provision in MAP-21 includes a "ratchet mechanism" to maintain solvency of the highway account by reducing FY2012 ObLim if the balance falls below certain thresholds. Any withdrawn ObLim would lapse, and a proportionate amount of contract authority would be rescinded. The calculation is to be made under year-long appropriations bills, not short-term continuing resolutions, to address the pending HTF shortfall and ensure spending stays within HTF means. This may increase pressure to find additional revenue options for the HTF. H.R. 7 proposes a $205 billion federal-aid highway program authorization over five years, with HTF obligation limitations set for each year. Congress has a history of overriding negative RABA calculations by drawing down the HTF balance. H.R. 7 proposes a $205 billion federal-aid highway program authorization over five years, with HTF obligation limitations set for each year. Some highway programs would be funded from a proposed Alternative Transportation Account, providing an additional obligation limitation of $2.7 billion annually for FY2013-FY2016. H.R. 7 includes a modified Equity Bonus Program with a guarantee that each state's total highway grants will equal at least 94% of the motor fuel taxes paid into the HTF. The House bill, H.R. 7, proposes a $205 billion federal-aid highway program authorization over five years, with an obligation limitation of $3.9 billion per year. It includes funding for various highway programs such as the Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality Program, Ferry Boats and Terminals, Puerto Rico Highways, and Territorial Highway Program. Additionally, the bill allows expanded tolling of the Interstate system and federal participation in projects to increase highway capacity and convert to toll facilities. H.R. 7 proposes a $205 billion federal-aid highway program authorization over five years with expanded tolling of the Interstate system. MAP-21 determines state apportionments for major programs using a single methodology. The amount available for apportionment by each state is based on their share of total nationwide apportionments and allocations received for FY2005-FY2009. Adjustments are made to ensure each state's combined apportionments will not be less than 95% of estimated tax payments made by highway users. It is unlikely adjustments will be needed due to excess federal highway spending over revenues. Additionally, an amount is based on each state's CMAQ percentage of total apportionments for FY2009, plus 10% of the state's. The new CMAQ program allocates a percentage of each state's apportionments for FY2009, along with 10% of the state's Surface Transportation Program funding for FY2009. The metropolitan planning amount is determined based on a state's apportionment ratio under Title 23 Section 134 for FY2009. The remaining initial amount is divided among four core programs, with 58% going to the National Highway program. The remaining core programs receive apportionments as follows: 58% for the National Highway Performance Program (NHPP), 29.3% for the Transportation Mobility Program (TMP), 7% for the Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP), and 5.7% for the National Freight Program (NFP). States with privatized toll roads would have their apportionments adjusted based on privatized lane mileage and vehicle miles traveled on those highways. The apportionments for states with privatized toll roads would be adjusted based on lane mileage and vehicle miles traveled. This adjustment would reduce apportionments for Illinois, Indiana, and Colorado, while increasing apportionments for all other states. Apportionments for states with privatized toll roads would be adjusted based on lane mileage and vehicle miles traveled. Illinois, Indiana, and Colorado would see a decrease in apportionments, while all other states would see an increase. Concerns about equity in federal highway spending were historically addressed through programs like SAFETEA's Equity Bonus Program, but MAP-21 does not have a similar program. Instead, MAP-21 determines the initial amount for each state based on their share of total funding from FY2005-FY2009 to resolve the donor-donee issue upfront. The adjustment mechanism in MAP-21 aims to resolve the "donor-donee" issue upfront by ensuring all states receive a 95% rate of return on their payments to the HTF. If Congress does not provide sufficient funding, adjustments may be necessary. Some states may prefer using their state return on payments to determine the "initial amount" instead of the state share of total FY2005-FY2009 funding. SAFETEA included 6,372 earmarks valued at $24.3 billion, with 67% being "below the line" earmarks that did not bring additional money to states. The remaining 33% were "above the line" earmarks that increased funds flowing to states. The extension legislation increased states' shares of highway program funding, benefiting states that previously obtained above-the-line earmarks. MAP-21 eliminated project earmarks but still allocated funding based on states' past earmark success under SAFETEA. MAP-21 reduced the number of funding programs by two-thirds, absorbing their eligibilities into new core programs. The five core programs plus metropolitan transportation planning would be authorized at $39.143 billion, reflecting the unequal distribution of earmarks among Members of Congress and states under SAFETEA. The NHPP program, the largest within the restructured Federal-Aid Highway program, would receive $20.5 billion for FY2012 and $21 billion for FY2013 to improve the National Highway System. It combines three SAFETEA core programs to achieve national performance goals. The NHPP program, funded with $20.5 billion for FY2012 and $21 billion for FY2013, aims to improve infrastructure condition, safety, mobility, and freight movement. It includes projects for highways, bridges, tunnels, ferry facilities, bicycle and pedestrian infrastructure, traffic monitoring, intelligent transportation systems, and environmental restoration within NHS corridors. The NHPP program focuses on infrastructure improvement, safety, mobility, and freight movement. States must develop asset management plans with performance metrics. Funds may be transferred if bridge conditions fall below minimum standards. This program aims to enhance federal-aid highways and bridges. The Transportation Modernization Program (TMP) aims to improve federal-aid highways and bridges by replacing SAFETEA's Surface Transportation Program. It includes funding for transit, carpool programs, congestion pricing, and other transportation enhancement activities. The authorization for TMP is approximately $10.5 billion annually for FY2012 and FY2013. The Transportation Modernization Program (TMP) funds various projects such as recreational trails, ferry facilities, border infrastructure, scenic roads, truck parking, safe routes to school, and natural habitat conservation. It also covers improvements to freight railroads, marine highways, and intermodal facilities under certain conditions. Maintenance and improvement of public roads within 10 miles of international borders are also eligible for TMP funds. The Transportation Modernization Program (TMP) funds various projects including public roads within 10 miles of international borders where federally owned vehicles make up over 50% of traffic. States face penalties if deficient bridge deck area increases. TMP funds are sub-apportioned within states based on population distribution in urbanized areas, areas with populations over 5,000, and other areas. The Appalachian Development Highway System is also included. The Transportation Modernization Program (TMP) would give states more flexibility in determining spending on the Appalachian Development Highway System (ADHS). The Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality Improvement Program (CMAQ) would be expanded under MAP-21, absorbing eligibilities of discontinued programs and receiving roughly $3.3 billion annually for FY2012 and FY2013. Eligibility for CMAQ funding would be expanded to include demand-shifting projects like telecommuting and ridesharing. The CMAQ program would be expanded to include demand-shifting projects like telecommuting and ridesharing. HSIP would continue to support safety improvement projects on road infrastructure. The High Risk Rural Roads Program and Rail-Highway Grade Crossing Program would be abolished. The NFP would be a new program. The NFP would be a new program funded at roughly $2 billion annually for FY2012 and FY2013, aimed at improving the condition and performance of a newly designated national freight network. MAP-21 would reduce the maximum percentage of funding that a state can transfer between programs from 50% to 20%, with restrictions on transferring TMP funding suballocated by population. H.R. 7 would consolidate or eliminate many programs, retaining core program structures while expanding the National Highway System Program and Surface Transportation Program. The Interstate Maintenance program would be folded into the NHS, and the Highway Safety Improvement Program would be retained. The 10% STP set-aside would remain. The 10% STP set-aside for Transportation Enhancements is eliminated in H.R. 7, which consolidates or eliminates many programs while retaining core program structures. The Interstate Maintenance program is folded into the National Highway System Program, and an additional $8 billion is provided for the Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality Improvement Program. H.R. 7 would allocate $70.4 billion for FY2013-FY2016 to expand funding for the National Highway System program. This would help with maintenance and repair of the Interstate Highway system and bridges on the NHS. Only projects on the NHS would be eligible for funding, and states would need to participate in state asset management. H.R. 7 would authorize $42.4 billion for FY2013-FY2014 for the Surface Transportation Program (STP), broadening its purpose to include construction, inspection, rehabilitation, and replacement of bridges and tunnels. The bill would eliminate the requirement for 10% of STP funds to be set aside for transportation enhancement purposes. H.R. 7 would modify the allocation of STP funds, allowing up to 15% to be used on roads classified as minor collectors in areas with populations under 5,000. It would also reduce the percentage of funds required to be spent on urbanized areas with populations over 200,000 from 62.5% to 50%. States must consult with local or rural planning organizations before obligating funds for projects in population areas of 5,000 to 200,000. H.R. 7 would provide $10.4 billion for FY2013-FY2014 for HSIP, requiring states to have their own highway safety improvement programs and state safety plans to receive funds. Plans must set safety goals, identify projects, and evaluate progress annually. Federal cost share would remain at 90%. H.R. 7 would provide $8 billion over FY2013-FY2014 from the proposed alternative transportation account for CMAQ, amending the program to guarantee each state a minimum 94% return in core program apportionments. The total authorization is $15.6 billion over two years, limiting the amount for the guarantee to $3.9 billion per year. Under SAFETEA, the EB authorization was for "such sums as necessary," with an estimated $40.9 billion needed in contract authority. If the $3.9 billion annual amount is insufficient to bring all states up to 94%, the STP authorization would be decreased. The Senate bill, Section 1107, clarifies eligibility criteria for ER funds for roads and bridges damaged by natural disasters or catastrophic failures. Roads already closed to traffic or scheduled for construction in the approved statewide transportation improvement plan at the time of the disaster would not be eligible for ER funds. The ER funds eligibility criteria for roads and bridges damaged by natural disasters or catastrophic failures are clarified under the Senate bill. The U.S. territories would not receive more than $20 million in a single fiscal year, and the $100 million ceiling on a single natural disaster or catastrophic failure in a single state would be eliminated. Section 1506 allows adjustments to the 180-day emergency period for federal government payment of repair costs. Additionally, 100% federal share may be allowed if repair costs exceed the annual state apportionment. The repair costs can exceed the annual state apportionment under H.R. 7, Section 1111. Reimbursement for debris removal is limited to costs not covered by the Stafford Act. U.S. territories are capped at $20 million per fiscal year for assistance. An emergency declaration is required for assistance, with states needing to provide a list of projects and costs within two days. The Senate bill proposes restructuring the Federal Lands Highways Programs to create the Federal Lands and Tribal Transportation Program, with three main components: Tribal Transportation Program, Federal Lands Transportation Program, and Federal Lands Access Program. Both MAP-21 and H.R. 7 would authorize funding for transportation research and education, with MAP-21 allocating $400 million annually and H.R. 7 allocating $440 million annually. Both bills include provisions for technology deployment programs and prize competitions to promote transportation innovations. Additionally, both bills direct the Department of Transportation to conduct studies on various aspects of transportation improvement. Both MAP-21 and H.R. 7 authorize grants for transportation research at university centers. They also emphasize the need to fully utilize the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund for infrastructure maintenance. Congress currently only appropriates half of the collected cargo tax for this purpose. House-passed H.R. 4348 includes language that would require the total level of budgetary resources provided for a fiscal year to equal the receipts credited to the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund, restricting the use of such amounts to harbor maintenance programs.
